answers: Marcel Proust [or Valentin Louis Georges Eugène Marcel Proust] (Proust’s secretary, Albert Nahmias, was possibly the inspiration for Albertine.)
Inferno [prompt on The Divine Comedy until read]
Alexander Blok [or Alexander Alexandrovich Blok]
parts: Name this author, the subject of a lecture series given by the artist Joseph Czapski (“CHAP-ski”) in a Soviet prison camp. His most famous work, translated by C. K. Scott Moncrieff, may feature a gender-swapped version of his secretary.

In Survival in Auschwitz, Primo Levi recites part of this work to a fellow prisoner. A reference to this first section of the Divine Comedy names a Solzhenitsyn novel about gulag technicians, The First Circle.

Eugenia Ginzburg wrote about reciting this author’s poetry in the gulags. The line “Black night, white snow” opens “The Twelve,” a poem by this author that describes Jesus leading Bolshevik guards in a massacre.

answers: AT&T [or American Telephone and Telegraph Company]
Bell [accept Bell System; accept Ma Bell or Baby Bells; accept Alexander Graham Bell]
Western Union
parts: Name this company that signed the Kingsbury Commitment to avoid one antitrust suit, but faced another in 1982. This company was purchased by its former subsidiary SBC in 2005.
After that antitrust suit, AT&T was forced to break up this “Ma” system into seven regional “Baby” systems. This system was named for AT&T’s founder, the inventor of the telephone.

In the Kingsbury Commitment, AT&T sold its shares in this company founded by Ezra Cornell, which created the first stock ticker. This rival of AT&T pivoted away from telephones after Elisha Gray lost a patent suit to Bell.

answers: theory of mind [or mentalizing; prompt on mind-reading; do not accept or prompt on “philosophy of mind” or “concept of mind”]
Jean Piaget
Nicaraguan Sign Language [or NSL]
parts: Name this ability that is often measured using false-belief tasks or the Sally–Anne test. Those tests display this ability, which allows people to distinguish between their own thoughts and knowledge and those of others.

Understanding false-belief tasks requires that children overcome their egocentrism through social interaction, as described by this theorist. This man divided development into stages like sensorimotor and preoperational.

Senghas and Pyer’s work on this spontaneously developed language shows that success in false-belief tasks depends on language maturity, not just socialization. Senghas studied this language’s Extensive Contact Period.

answers: hearing tests [accept audiometry or pure tone audiometry]
conduction [accept air conduction or bone conduction; accept conductive hearing loss]
tonotopic organization [or tonotopy; or cochleotopy; accept tonotopic map]
parts: Name these tests. In the most common version of these tests, tones are played at different frequencies via headphones to determine the minimum threshold for a parameter measured in decibels.

Audiograms from hearing tests can distinguish between sensorineural hearing loss and hearing loss caused by defects in this process. In this process, vibrations in air are transmitted through middle ear bones to the inner ear.

Hearing loss can change the primary auditory cortex’s organization, which is normally described by this term. The varying stiffness of the basilar membrane spatially separates frequencies, resulting in this organization as well.

answers: spoken word poetry [or slam poetry] [prompt on poems or poetry or dub poetry until read; accept poetry performed out loud or equivalents;
the revolution [accept “The Revolution Will Not Be Televised”]
Joy Harjo (The poem is “She Had Some Horses.”)
parts: Name this type of work that includes the “dub” style of Linton Kwesi Johnson. One work in this format describes an event that “will not go better with Coke” and “will not fight germs that may cause bad breath.”
A spoken word poem by Gil Scott-Heron claims that “you will not be able to plug in, turn on, and cop out” because this event “will not be televised.”

This poet performed spoken word with the band Poetic Justice in “Letter from the End of the Twentieth Century.” In a list-formatted poem, this author described animals who “laughed too much” and “licked razor blades.”

answers: Giuseppe Verdi
Arthur Honegger (“ar-TOOR oh-neh-GAIR”)
Julius Eastman
parts: Giovanna d’Arco is an opera by this composer, who also wrote Rigoletto and La Traviata.
The oratorio Jean d’Arc au bûcher, featuring a prominent part for ondes Martenot (“OND mart-NO”), is by this Swiss member of Les Six (“lay seese”) and composer of Pacific 231.

The Holy Presence of Joan d’Arc is a work for cello ensemble by this African-American minimalist composer, who used indeterminate notation and gave several works provocative titles like Gay Guerrilla.

answers: Christian democracy [accept Christian Democratic Union of Germany; accept Christlich Demokratische Union Deutschlands; accept Democrazia Cristiana]
Chile [or Republic of Chile]
Cuba [or Republic of Cuba]
parts: Name this religion-infused political ideology. A party of this type manufactured an “economic miracle” in the 1940s and 1950s when it cut inflation and rapidly rebuilt after World War II.
Patricio Aylwin and Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle, two leaders from this country’s Christian Democratic Party, served successively as president after the military rule of Augusto Pinochet.

Oswaldo Payá, a dissident in this country, founded a Christian democratic party called the Christian Liberation Movement, as well as the Varela Project. This country suffered an economic depression called the “Special Period.”

answers: preterism [accept full preterism; accept partial preterism]
the Transfiguration of Christ
Israel [or State of Israel; or Medinat Yisrael]
parts: Name this school of thought that interprets some or all prophecies in the Bible as having already been fulfilled.
Other preterists interpret that the “kingdom of God” in Luke 9:27 refers to this event, where a radiant Jesus meets with Elijah and Moses on Mount Tabor.

According to many non-preterists, the phrase “some who are standing here” refers to people born during the reestablishment of this nation, and who are expected to rebuild the Third Temple in this nation’s disputed capital.

answers: Lauryn Hill [or Lauryn Noelle Hill; accept The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill]
Cardi B [or Belcalis Marlenis Almánzar; prompt on Cardi]
Rapsody [or Marianna Evans]
parts: Name this artist who, with Wyclef Jean (“WHY-clef zhon”) and Pras Michel, formed the hip-hop group The Fugees. Her only solo album is titled for her “Miseducation.”
This other musician interpolated lyrics from “Ex-Factor” on her song “Be Careful.” Both that song and her hit single “Bodak Yellow” appear on her 2018 album Invasion of Privacy.

This rapper sampled “Ex-Factor” throughout “My Song,” which opens “I ain’t the next Ms. Hill.” This artist behind the 2019 album Eve has a guest verse on “Complexion” from Kendrick Lamar’s album To Pimp a Butterfly.

answers: cumulative distribution function [or CDF; do not accept or prompt on “probability density function” or “PDF”]
nonparametric statistics
normal distribution [or Gaussian distribution; or Laplace–Gauss distribution]
parts: Name this type of function, usually written capital F. One of these functions evaluated at a point x gives the probability that a random variable is less than or equal to x.

The Kolmogorov–Smirnov test is commonly used in this branch of statistics, whose techniques include kernel density estimation. This branch of statistics does not assume that the data come from a specific family of distributions.
A common assumption in parametric statistics is that error terms follow this distribution, whose density is shaped like a bell curve.

answers: Scrovegni (“scro-VAIN-yee”) Chapel [or Cappella degli Scrovegni; or Arena Chapel] (Pisani wrote I volti segreti di Giotto, in which he argued that each vice should be paired with its opposite virtue, rather than going straight through each set.)
gardens [accept Minerva Expelling the Vices from the Garden of Virtues or The Expulsion from the Garden of Eden]
Hercules [or Heracles; accept The Choice of Hercules or the judgment of Hercules or Hercules at the crossroads]
parts: Name this building whose vices and virtues are thought to omit avarice, potentially because of a patron’s reputation for usury. This chapel’s blue ceiling depicts stars and four prophets around the Madonna and Child.
Minerva expels the Vices from one of these places in a Triumph of the Virtues by Mantegna. An angel drives Adam and Eve from one of these places in a Massacio fresco.

Vice hides a dagger and sphinx behind her skirt and struggles with Virtue over this figure in a Paolo Veronese painting. Annibale Carracci (“ah-NEE-ba-lay ka-RAH-chee”) also depicted this figure’s choice between allegorical female figures of Vice and Virtue.

answers: Africana [accept An Introduction to Africana Philosophy]
nihilism [or word forms; accept “Nihilism in Black America”]
encyclopedias [or Encyclopédie; prompt on reference works or dictionaries]
parts: Give this specific adjective. Lewis Gordon wrote an introduction to the branch of philosophy of this name, which retroactively includes the work of thinkers like Anténor Firmin, Anna Julia Cooper, and Frantz Fanon (“fah-NAWN”).

Lewis Gordon’s Existentia Africana discusses many examples of Black existentialist thought, such as Cornel West’s concept of “keeping faith” as an antidote to this position. Generally, this position holds that nothing matters.

Kwame Appiah (“APP-ee-ah”) and Henry Louis Gates completed Africana, one of these works envisioned by W. E. B. DuBois. A “tree” of knowledge is described in Jean d’Alembert’s (“dal-om-BARE’s”) preface to an earlier one of these works.

answers: The Famished Road
Ben Okri
The Stranger [or L’Etranger; or The Outsider]
parts: Name this novel that opens with the line “In the beginning there was a river.” A man in this novel fights a spirit in a white suit and tells the protagonist about a giant who eats himself until only his stomach remains.
This author wrote about the Party of the Rich and the Party of the Poor in The Famished Road and its sequel, Songs of Enchantment. He also wrote the 2020 novel The Freedom Artist.
In 2018, Okri adapted this Albert Camus novel into a play, which he accompanied with a short film from the perspective of “the Arab,” who is murdered by this novel’s protagonist.

answers: nearly free electron model [or NFE model; or quasi-free electron model; prompt on free electron model]
discrete Fourier transform [accept Fourier series or Fourier expansion or inverse discrete Fourier transform; prompt on DFT]
Schrödinger equation
parts: Name this model in which non-interacting particles are weakly perturbed by the presence of a periodic ionic lattice. In complementary situations, the tight-binding model might be used instead of this model.

This operation decomposes the periodic potential of the nearly free electron model into components labeled by reciprocal lattice vectors. This operation writes “U of R” as a sum over G of “U-sub-G times e to the iGR.”
The purpose of the nearly free electron model is to find solutions to this basic equation of quantum mechanics, whose time-dependent form describes the evolution of a wavefunction.

answers: Otto [accept Otto I or Otto the Great or Otto II]
Doge of Venice
Catherine de’ Medici [prompt on Medici]
parts: Give this name that was used by the Holy Roman Emperor who defeated the Magyars at Lechfeld and began an artistic renaissance in the empire.

Another Byzantine princess, Maria Argyropoulina (“AR-juh-ro-poo-LEE-na”), used a golden fork during her marriage to a holder of this position. Geoffrey of Villehardouin (“vee-lard-WANN”) disputes that Manuel I Komnenos angrily blinded a holder of this position.
Through her marriage to Henry II, this French queen also may have introduced forks, and one of her chefs supposedly invented macaroons. She likely instigated the St. Bartholomew’s Day Massacre.

answers: The Buried Giant
Never Let Me Go
Kazuo Ishiguro
parts: Name this novel set in a mystical Dark Age Britain, in which Axl and Beatrice search for their son. Wistan and Gawain seek to kill Querig, whose presence cloaks the land in mist, in this novel.

In this novel by the author of The Buried Giant, Kathy acts as a “carer” for Ruth and the non-artistic Tommy. This novel is named for a Judy Bridgewater song on a tape that Kathy dances to while pretending to hold a baby.
The Buried Giant and Never Let Me Go are novels by this author who created the butler Stevens, who regrets his inability to “banter,” in The Remains of the Day.

answers: Grímnismál [accept The Lay of Grímnir]
riddles [prompt on puzzles or brain teasers or equivalents; prompt on wits] (Odin bests Heidrek while disguised as Gestumblindi in the Hervarar Saga.)
Mead of Poetry [or Poetic Mead or Liquor of Hnitbjörg; prompt on mead] (The inferior part of the Mead of Poetry became the “poetaster’s share.”)
parts: Name this section of the Poetic Edda in which Odin introduces himself as the namesake traveler in a test of hospitality, only for Geirröth to unwittingly torture him.

Disguised as Gestumblindi, Odin wins a contest of these things by asking what Odin whispered in Baldr’s ear at his funeral. A similar story in the Vafthrudnismal (“vahf-throod-niss-mall”) inspired a contest of these questions between Bilbo and Gollum.

In the Skáldskaparmal (“skald-ska-par-mal”), Odin poses as Bölverk to steal this substance from Suttungr. Odin spends three nights with Gunnlöd to obtain this substance, and later drops an inferior portion of it.

answers: cars [or equivalents; accept window of a car; accept Volkswagen Beetle, BMW 2002, Ford Escort or Mustang or LTD, Mercury Capri or Grand Marquis, Pontiac Grand Prix, or other specific types of car; prompt on windows] (Spindle is by Dustin Shuler.)
music videos [prompt on video; prompt on album; accept visual album]
Joan Miró [or Joan Miró i Ferrà; accept Joan Miró Prize]
parts: Name these objects. Eight of these objects were impaled on a spike in the demolished sculpture Spindle, and Chris Burden crucified himself on one of these objects in the 1974 performance piece Trans-Fixed.

Ever is Over All may have inspired a work of this type in which Beyoncé smashes car windows with a baseball bat to the tune of her song “Hold Up.” A police car sinking into water features in a work of this type made for Beyoncé’s “Formation.”

In 2009, Rist won a prize named for this Catalan artist, whose multi-material structure The Sun, The Moon, and One Star includes a fork-like structure. Hemingway transported this artist’s painting The Farm on top of a car.

answers: Swern oxidation [prompt on oxidation] (As the textbook explains, an “O in brackets” is shorthand for oxidation by an unspecified reagent.)

hypervalent [or hypervalence; or expanded octet; accept any answer describing an atom that violates the octet rule; accept any answer describing an atom with more than an octet, more than eight valence electrons, or more than four bonds; prompt on hypercoordination]
noble gases [or group 18; or aerogens; prompt on inert gases]
parts: Name this reaction in which oxalyl chloride, DMSO, and a weak base convert an alcohol to a carbonyl (“car-bo-NEEL”), yielding foul-smelling dimethyl sulfide as a byproduct.

Dess–Martin periodinane (“pur-eye-ODD-in-ane”), which performs a similar reaction, has this unusual property at its iodine atom. Linus Pauling proposed that molecules like sulfur hexafluoride achieve this property through sp³d² (“S-P-three-D-two”) hybridization.
Hypervalency is especially common among compounds formed by this group of elements, since those in period 2 and below already have eight valence electrons.

answers: Leila Khaled
Jordan [or Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan]
Moshe Dayan (“MO-sheh da-YAHN”)
parts: Name this member of the PFLP, the first woman to hijack a plane. She was a participant in the Dawson’s Field hijackings and had earlier hijacked a TWA flight to Tel Aviv.

The Dawson’s Field hijackings took place during a conflict between the PLO and this country known as Black September. This country’s Hashemite king Abdullah I reneged on his promise to support Israeli independence.
In 1970, Palestinians carried out the Sabena hijacking, whose end was negotiated by this defense minister of Israel. This eyepatch-wearing general led Israeli forces during the Six-Day War.
